article.description:
Stanford lost in the first round of the NCAA Tournament ... and Trent Johnson's 13th-ranked Cardinal didn't get a pass in the season opener either. UC Irvine used its crucial height advantage to pull a
79-63 upset victory Saturday.
article.headline: Anteaters pull upset in sixth meeting between schools
article.story: STANFORD, Calif. (AP) -- Stanford got outhustled, outmuscled, outrebounded and outshot -- and coach Trent Johnson could hardly believe his eyes. "Ugly, ugly, ugly, ugly," the second-year Cardinal coach said. Ross Schraeder scored 19 points and UC Irvine used an impressive shooting performance and just plain hard work to shock No. 13 Stanford 79-63 in the Cardinal's season-opener Saturday, earning coach Pat Douglass his 500th career victory. Shamar Armstrong scored six straight points in the final 3:19, and the Anteaters took advantage of a significant height advantage to pound the ball inside at every opportunity against a Stanford squad missing starting forward Matt Haryasz, who sprained his ankle in practice Friday. "It's sure nice to win No. 500 in a game like this against Stanford, a team and program I respect so much," Douglass said. "We shot well in our last game, and we stayed in sync today." Darren Fells added 18 points, nine rebounds, five assists and two blocks for UC Irvine (2-1), which beat Stanford for the first time in six meetings. Stanford, picked to finish second in the Pac-10 behind Arizona, beat the Anteaters in Maples Pavilion 84-57 in December 2002 and again the following season on the road. Stanford cut the lead to 61-56 on Grunfeld's basket with 3:54 left, then Armstrong hit a tough 3-pointer on the other end with the shot clock winding down. On the next trip down, Armstrong converted a three-point play. "That 3-pointer seemed to be one of the keys," said Douglass, in his ninth season at Irvine and 25th overall. "You could see the wind go out of their sails on that basket." The last time the Anteaters beat an opponent ranked higher than Stanford was on March 11, 1988, a 74-70 win over seventh-ranked UNLV. Dan Grunfeld scored 18 of his 29 points in the first half, making an impressive season debut after his breakout junior season was cut short by a knee injury and surgery. But he looked tired at times in the second half trying to carry the majority of the load on offense while also grabbing nine rebounds. Cardinal point guard Chris Hernandez missed several easy shots and finished with 13 points and five assists. Stanford's only lead came 4 seconds into the game on a layin by Grunfeld. "When a team gets up on you, it's a long game," he said. Schraeder made all six of his field-goal tries in the first half, including three 3-pointers, as the Anteaters shot 69.2 percent (18-for-26), on the way to a 43-35 halftime lead. They were 6-of-8 from 3-point range. Schraeder, a 6-foot-5 senior guard and the team's leading scorer from last season, had plenty of help, too. Mark Kelley added 10 points and three others had either eight or nine points. "From start to finish, they were the aggressor and they basically gave us an old-fashioned tail-whipping," Johnson said. "I can't figure out if there's anything we did well individually or collectively. ... The thing that impressed me the most was their level of toughness. From our standpoint, that's unacceptable." The Anteaters were coming off a 94-40 victory over Mississippi Valley State on Nov. 11 in which they established a school record for margin of victory against a Division I opponent. Haryasz is expected to be sidelined for at least a couple of days. Peter Prowitt replaced Haryasz in the staring lineup and struggled. Johnson began his second season with a tough defeat after the Cardinal struggled with injuries and other issues last season. Tim Morris missed the final 19 games because of academic problems and the Cardinal dressed in a trailer and started the season with seven road games before renovations on Maples Pavilion were complete. Stanford lost in the first round of the NCAA tournament, ending a string of 10 straight trips to the second round. One of the Cardinal's problems last season was defending the 3-pointer, which surfaced again Saturday. "UC Irvine did a great job of showing us what we really need to work on," Hernandez said. "Everybody has to look at themselves and what they need to do better. They seemed pretty in sync. Everybody knew what they were doing. Regardless, we've been practicing 3½ or 4 weeks. "There's a lot of time to improve, and that's what we need to do."

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
